qas.question: Tagalog is what kind of language?
From what language is a large proportion of Tagalog derived?
What is an example of a Sanskrit loanword used in Southeast Asian languages?
What is the meaning of the Sanskrit loanword "bhāṣā?"
What is an example of a traditional language that derives much of its vocabulary from Sanskrit?
Where were many Sanskrit words found?

What is the meaning of bhasa?
Where does traditional Malay get many of its loanwords?
In what languages are Tagalog loan words found?
Which language from Indonesia is not derived from Sanskrit?
What languages from the Austronesian languages is not derived from Arabic?
What language loan words does Arabic use?
What language is Spanish derived from?

context: Many Sanskrit loanwords are also found in <a5_0><b10_0>Austronesian languages<b10_0/><a5_0/>, such as <a6_0>Javanese<a6_0/>, particularly the older form in which nearly half the vocabulary is borrowed. Other Austronesian languages, such as <b12_0>traditional <a4_0><b11_0>Malay<b11_0/><a4_0/> and modern Indonesian<b12_0/>, also derive much of their vocabulary from <a9_0>Sanskrit<a9_0/>, albeit to a lesser extent, with a larger proportion derived from Arabic. Similarly, <a0_0>Philippine<a0_0/> languages such as <b14_0>Tagalog<b14_0/> have some <b13_0>Sanskrit loanwords<b13_0/>, although more are derived from <a1_0>Spanish<a1_0/>. A Sanskrit loanword encountered in many Southeast Asian languages is the word <a2_0><a7_0>bhāṣā<a7_0/><a2_0/>, or <a3_0><a8_0>spoken language<a8_0/><a3_0/>, which is used to refer to the names of many languages.
